accordion.title: Accordion
accordion.description: The Accordion component creates collapsible content sections that can expand and collapse, helping to organize information hierarchically and save screen space.
accordion.content:
Usage



API Reference

Accordion Props

 void',
                hintText: 'function',
            },
            { content: '' },
        ],
    ]}
    className="mb-8"
    emptyMessage="No props available"
    loadingMessage="Loading props..."
/>

AccordionItem Props



Features

- Visual Variants: Two distinct styles - bordered and borderless for different design contexts
- Selection Modes: Single or multiple item expansion with controlled state management
- Flexible Layout: Customizable chevron positioning (left or right side)
- Rich Content Support: Multiple content slots for icons, subtitles, and additional elements
- Interactive States: Comprehensive state management including hover, active, and disabled states
- Accessibility First: Full keyboard navigation with ARIA compliance and screen reader support
- Smooth Animations: Built-in expand/collapse animations with smooth transitions
- Responsive Design: Adapts to different screen sizes with responsive design tokens
- Controlled/Uncontrolled: Support for both controlled and uncontrolled component patterns
- Customizable Styling: Extensive theming through design tokens for consistent branding

Usage Examples

Basic Accordion

Simple accordion with border styling



No Border Accordion

Accordion without border styling for a cleaner look



Multiple Selection Accordion

Allow multiple items to be expanded simultaneously



Accordion with Icons and Slots

Rich accordion items with icons and additional content



Controlled Accordion

Accordion with controlled state management



Disabled Accordion Item

Accordion item that cannot be expanded



Component Tokens

You can style the accordion component using the following tokens:



Behavior

Expansion Modes

- Single Mode: Only one accordion item can be expanded at a time (default behavior)
- Multiple Mode: Multiple items can be expanded simultaneously when isMultiple={true}
- Default Values: Set initially expanded items using defaultValue prop

State Management

- Controlled: Use value and onValueChange props for external state control
- Uncontrolled: Component manages its own internal state when no value prop is provided
- Disabled Items: Individual items can be disabled while maintaining visual consistency

Animations

- Smooth Transitions: Built-in CSS transitions for expand/collapse animations
- Performance Optimized: Uses transform and opacity changes for smooth rendering
- Accessibility Friendly: Respects user's motion preferences

Accessibility

- Keyboard Navigation: Full keyboard support with Enter/Space to toggle items
- ARIA Compliance: Proper aria-expanded, aria-controls, and aria-labelledby attributes
- Screen Reader Support: Descriptive labels and state announcements
- Focus Management: Clear focus indicators and logical tab order
- Semantic HTML: Uses proper heading and button elements for structure
- High Contrast: Supports high contrast mode and custom color schemes

AccordionType



AccordionChevronPosition

alert.title: Alert
alert.description: The Alert component is a versatile notification element used to display important messages to users with multiple variants, styles, and interactive options.
alert.content:
Usage



API Reference

 void', hintText: 'function' },

AlertAction Type

The AlertAction type defines the structure for action buttons:

 void', hintText: 'function' },

Features

- 7 Semantic Variants: Primary, Success, Warning, Error, Purple, Orange, and Neutral for different message types
- 2 Visual Styles: Subtle (filled background) and No Fill (outline only) for different design contexts
- Flexible Actions: Support for primary and secondary action buttons with customizable placement
- Dismissible: Optional close button with callback functionality
- Custom Icons: Support for custom icons to enhance visual communication
- Responsive Layout: Automatic layout adjustment based on content and screen size
- Accessible Design: Full keyboard navigation and screen reader support
- Action Placement: Buttons can be positioned on the right or bottom for optimal layout
- Max Width Control: Built-in max-width of 900px for optimal readability
- Theme Integration: Consistent styling through design tokens

Usage Examples

Basic Information Alert

Simple alert with heading and description only



Success Alert with Close Button

Alert confirming successful action with dismissible option



Warning Alert with Actions

Alert requiring user decision with action buttons



Error Alert with Custom Icon

Error alert with custom icon for enhanced visual communication



Alert with Bottom Action Placement

Alert with action buttons positioned below the content



No Fill Style Alert

Alert with transparent background and border-only styling



Alert with Only Close Button

Alert with automatic bottom placement when only close button is provided



Component Tokens

You can style the Alert component using the following tokens:



Behavior

Action Placement Logic

- Right Placement: When both primary and secondary actions are provided
- Bottom Placement: When actionPlacement={AlertActionPlacement.BOTTOM} is explicitly set
- Automatic Bottom: When only onClose is provided without other actions

Close Button Behavior

- Auto-positioning: Close button automatically moves to bottom when no other actions are present
- Always Visible: Close button remains accessible when onClose prop is provided
- Icon Consistency: Uses standard X icon from Lucide React

Responsive Behavior

- Max Width: Component has a maximum width of 900px for optimal readability
- Flexible Layout: Content and actions adapt to available space
- Mobile Friendly: Action buttons stack appropriately on smaller screens

Accessibility

- Semantic HTML: Uses proper ARIA roles and landmarks for alert content
- Keyboard Navigation: All interactive elements are keyboard accessible
- Screen Reader Support: Proper announcements for alert content and state changes
- Focus Management: Clear focus indicators on all interactive elements
- Color Independence: Alert meaning conveyed through text, not color alone
- High Contrast: Supports high contrast mode and custom color schemes

AlertVariant



AlertStyle



AlertActionPlacement

breadcrumb.title: Breadcrumb
breadcrumb.description: The Breadcrumb component provides navigation context by showing the current page's location within a site hierarchy, helping users understand where they are and navigate back.
breadcrumb.content:
Usage



API Reference



BreadcrumbItemType

Each item in the items array should have the following structure:



Features

- Hierarchical navigation display with clear visual separators
- Automatic overflow handling for long navigation paths (max 4 visible items)
- Responsive design that adapts to different screen sizes
- Support for custom icons and content through left/right slots
- Active state styling for the current page (last item)
- Keyboard accessible navigation with proper focus management
- Ellipsis menu for collapsed items (when more than 4 items)
- Consistent spacing and typography following design tokens

Usage Examples

Basic Breadcrumb

Simple breadcrumb with text-only navigation



Breadcrumb with Icons

Breadcrumb items with left slot icons



Long Navigation Path

Breadcrumb with overflow handling (shows ellipsis for middle items)



Breadcrumb with Right Slots

Breadcrumb items with additional content on the right



Single Item Breadcrumb

Breadcrumb with just one item (shows as active)



Empty Breadcrumb

Breadcrumb gracefully handles empty array



Complex Navigation with Mixed Content

Breadcrumb with various combinations of slots



Component Tokens

You can style the breadcrumb component using the following tokens:



Behavior

Overflow Handling

- Up to 4 items: All items are displayed
- More than 4 items: Shows first item + ellipsis + last 3 items
- Ellipsis button: Indicates collapsed items (menu functionality planned)

Active State

- The last item in the breadcrumb is considered "active" (current page)
- Active items use different styling (color, font weight)
- Active items are not clickable (no href applied)

Navigation

- All items except the last one are clickable links
- Proper semantic HTML structure for screen readers
- Keyboard navigation support through standard link behavior

Accessibility

- Semantic HTML: Uses proper link elements for navigation
- ARIA Support: Proper roles and labels for screen readers
- Keyboard Navigation: Standard tab navigation through links
- Visual Hierarchy: Clear distinction between active and inactive states
- Focus Management: Visible focus indicators for keyboard users

button-group.title: Button Group
button-group.description: The ButtonGroup component is a container that groups multiple Button components together with flexible layout options and automatic positioning for cohesive action interfaces.
button-group.content:
Usage



API Reference

 | ReactElement[]',
                hintText: 'React elements',
            },
            { content: '' },
        ],
    ]}
    className="mb-8"
    emptyMessage="No props available"
    loadingMessage="Loading props..."
/>

Features

- 2 Layout Modes: Horizontal (default) and vertical stacked layouts for different design contexts
- Automatic Positioning: Intelligent button positioning with left, center, and right positioning in stacked mode
- Seamless Integration: Works exclusively with Button components for consistent styling
- Smart Spacing: Automatic gap management - 10px for horizontal, 0px for stacked layout
- Dynamic Children: Supports any number of Button components as children
- Position Awareness: Automatically sets buttonGroupPosition prop for stacked buttons
- Flexible Styling: Inherits all Button component styling capabilities
- Responsive Design: Adapts to container constraints and screen sizes
- Type Safety: TypeScript support with proper Button component validation
- Clean Rendering: Optimized rendering with React.cloneElement for stacked mode

Usage Examples

Basic Horizontal Group

Default horizontal layout with standard spacing



Stacked Vertical Group

Vertical layout with connected button styling



Form Action Buttons

Common form submission pattern



Navigation Button Group

Stacked navigation menu with different button types



Dialog Action Buttons

Standard dialog confirmation pattern



Toolbar Actions

Multiple action buttons in horizontal layout



Loading State Group

Button group with loading states



Mixed Size Buttons

Buttons with different sizes in one group



Component Tokens

ButtonGroup uses the Button component's tokens for styling. The container itself has minimal styling:



Behavior

Layout Modes

- Horizontal (Default): Buttons arranged side-by-side with 10px gap
- Stacked: Buttons arranged vertically with 0px gap for connected appearance

Automatic Positioning

- First Button: Gets buttonGroupPosition="left" in stacked mode
- Middle Buttons: Get buttonGroupPosition="center" in stacked mode
- Last Button: Gets buttonGroupPosition="right" in stacked mode
- Single Button: Gets buttonGroupPosition="left" in stacked mode

Children Management

- Type Safety: Only accepts Button components as children
- Dynamic Rendering: Automatically handles single or multiple Button children
- Prop Injection: Adds positioning props to buttons in stacked mode
- Key Management: Preserves existing keys or generates index-based keys

Responsive Behavior

- Container Adaptation: Adapts to parent container constraints
- Button Scaling: Individual buttons maintain their responsive behavior
- Overflow Handling: Horizontal groups may wrap based on Button properties

Accessibility

- Focus Management: Maintains proper tab order through button sequence
- Keyboard Navigation: Standard button keyboard navigation (Tab, Enter, Space)
- Screen Reader Support: Each button maintains its individual accessibility features
- Semantic Structure: Uses proper button semantics for each child component
- ARIA Compliance: Inherits ARIA attributes from individual Button components
- High Contrast: Supports high contrast mode through Button component styling

Layout Specifications

Horizontal Layout (Default)



Stacked Layout



Best Practices

When to Use Horizontal Layout

- Form action buttons (Cancel, Submit)
- Dialog confirmations (No, Yes)
- Navigation controls (Previous, Next)
- Toolbar actions with limited buttons

When to Use Stacked Layout

- Vertical navigation menus
- Action lists in sidebars
- Mobile-first button groups
- When vertical space is preferred over horizontal

Button Combinations

- Primary + Secondary: Most common pattern for forms
- Multiple Secondary: For equal-weight actions
- Danger + Secondary: For destructive confirmations
- Success + Secondary: For positive confirmations

You can style the Button component using the following tokens:



Behavior

Loading State

- Spinner Display: Shows loading spinner and hides text content
- Disabled Interaction: Button becomes non-interactive during loading
- Visual Feedback: Provides clear indication of ongoing process

Disabled State

- Visual Changes: Reduced opacity and muted colors
- Interaction Prevention: Click events are prevented
- Focus Management: Button cannot receive keyboard focus

Icon Positioning

- Leading Icons: Positioned before text with proper spacing
- Trailing Icons: Positioned after text with proper spacing
- Icon Only: Centers icon when no text is present

Size Scaling

- Proportional Scaling: All elements scale proportionally with size
- Icon Sizing: Icons automatically resize based on button size
- Padding Adjustment: Internal spacing adjusts for optimal proportions

Accessibility

- Keyboard Navigation: Full keyboard support with Enter and Space key activation
- Focus Indicators: Clear visual focus indicators for keyboard users
- Screen Reader Support: Proper labeling and state announcements
- ARIA Attributes: Appropriate aria-disabled and aria-pressed attributes
- Color Independence: Button functionality conveyed through more than color alone
- High Contrast: Supports high contrast mode and custom color schemes

Component Tokens

You can style the Checkbox component using the following tokens:



Behavior

State Management

- Controlled: Use checked and onCheckedChange props for external state control
- Uncontrolled: Use defaultChecked for internal state management
- Indeterminate: Special state for partial selection scenarios

Interactive States

- Default: Normal interactive state with hover effects
- Hover: Visual feedback on mouse hover
- Disabled: Non-interactive state with reduced opacity
- Error: Red styling to indicate validation errors

Form Integration

- Required Field: Visual indicators and validation support
- Value Handling: Proper value attribute for form submissions
- Validation: Error state styling for failed validation

Accessibility Features

- Keyboard Navigation: Tab navigation and Space key activation
- Screen Reader: Proper labeling and state announcements
- Focus Indicators: Clear visual focus indicators

Accessibility

- ARIA Compliance: Proper aria-checked, aria-disabled, and aria-required attributes
- Keyboard Navigation: Full keyboard support with Tab and Space key activation
- Screen Reader Support: Descriptive labels and state announcements
- Focus Management: Clear focus indicators with proper contrast
- Label Association: Proper label-input association using htmlFor attributes
- Error Announcements: Screen reader announcements for error states
- High Contrast: Supports high contrast mode and custom color schemes

Enums

CheckboxSize



Checkbox States



Best Practices

When to Use

- Multiple Selection: When users need to select multiple options
- Terms Acceptance: For accepting terms, conditions, or agreements
- Settings/Preferences: For enabling/disabling features or options
- Form Controls: As part of larger forms for data collection

Label Guidelines

- Clear and Concise: Use descriptive labels that clearly explain what will happen
- Action-Oriented: Frame labels as actions (e.g., "Enable notifications")
- Positive Language: Use positive phrasing when possible
- Context Specific: Provide additional context through subtext when needed

Indeterminate State

- Partial Selection: Use when representing a partially selected state
- Parent-Child Relationships: Common in hierarchical lists or tree structures
- Group Selection: When some but not all items in a group are selected

Features

- Mobile Optimized: Responsive design with mobile drawer on small screens
- Single Date Mode: Option to select single dates instead of ranges
- Date Validation: Built-in validation with min/max date constraints

- Keyboard Navigation: Full keyboard accessibility support
- Flexible Formatting: Configurable date display formats

Behavior

Date Selection Flow

- Single Click: Select single date or start of range
- Range Selection: Click start date, then end date to complete range
- Visual Feedback: Highlight selected dates and range preview
- Validation: Ensure end date is after start date

Mobile Experience

- Drawer Interface: Full-screen drawer on mobile devices
- Touch Optimized: Large touch targets for mobile interaction
- Preset Integration: Quick access to common date ranges
- Time Picker: Scrollable time selection interface

Keyboard Navigation

- Tab Navigation: Navigate between inputs and calendar
- Arrow Keys: Navigate calendar grid
- Enter/Space: Select dates and activate controls
- Escape: Close picker without selection

Preset Functionality

- Quick Selection: Common date ranges (Today, Last 7 days, etc.)
- Custom Presets: Support for custom preset configurations
- Smart Defaults: Intelligent preset suggestions based on context
- Mobile Adaptation: Streamlined presets for mobile interfaces

Best Practices

When to Use DateRangePicker

- Analytics Dashboards: Date range selection for data analysis
- Booking Systems: Hotel, flight, and event booking date selection
- Report Generation: Selecting time periods for reports
- Scheduling: Meeting and event scheduling interfaces
- Data Filtering: Filtering datasets by date ranges

Mobile Considerations

- Drawer Mode: Use useDrawerOnMobile={true} for better mobile UX
- Preset Optimization: Consider skipQuickFiltersOnMobile for simpler mobile UI
- Touch Targets: Ensure adequate spacing for touch interaction
- Responsive Design: Test across different mobile screen sizes

Date Range Configuration

- Logical Constraints: Set appropriate min/max dates for your use case
- Future/Past Restrictions: Use disableFutureDates or disablePastDates as needed
- Format Consistency: Use consistent date formats across your application
- Time Zone Handling: Consider time zone implications for your users

Accessibility Guidelines

- Label Association: Provide clear labels for screen readers
- Keyboard Support: Ensure full keyboard navigation functionality
- Focus Management: Maintain proper focus flow through the interface
- Error Communication: Provide accessible error messages for invalid selections
- ARIA Labels: Use appropriate ARIA labels for complex calendar interactions

Performance Optimization

- State Management: Use appropriate state management for complex applications
- Debouncing: Consider debouncing for expensive operations triggered by date changes
- Memory Management: Clean up event listeners and timers properly
- Lazy Loading: Consider lazy loading for large calendar ranges

Form Integration

- Controlled Components: Always use controlled date range state
- Validation: Integrate with form validation libraries
- Submission Handling: Properly format dates for API submission
- Reset Functionality: Implement proper form reset behavior
- Default Values: Provide sensible default date ranges when appropriate

User Experience Guidelines

- Clear Labels: Use descriptive labels and placeholders
- Visual Feedback: Show clear selection states and hover effects
- Error Handling: Provide helpful error messages for invalid selections
- Loading States: Show loading indicators during data fetching
- Confirmation: Consider confirmation steps for critical date selections

Data Handling

- Time Zone Consistency: Handle time zones consistently across your application
- Date Formatting: Format dates appropriately for display and storage
- Range Validation: Validate date ranges on both client and server
- Edge Cases: Handle edge cases like leap years and daylight saving time
- Persistence: Consider persisting user's preferred date ranges

Features

- Full-Screen Overlay: Uses DrawerPortal and DrawerOverlay to render above all app content with proper z-index stacking
- Multi-Directional: Slide from any side (top, bottom, left, right) with responsive positioning
- Modular Components: Composable header, body, and footer components for flexible layouts
- Snap Points: Support for multiple snap positions on bottom/top drawers
- Drag Handle: Optional drag handle for bottom/top drawers with gesture support
- Mobile Optimized: Responsive design with mobile-specific positioning and offsets
- Overlay Control: Optional modal overlay with backdrop click dismissal
- Nested Support: Ability to stack drawers for complex navigation flows
- Built on Vaul: Leverages Vaul library for robust gesture and animation support
- Custom Styling: Comprehensive token system for complete visual customization
- Accessibility First: Full keyboard navigation, focus management, and screen reader support
- Content-Driven Height: Automatic sizing based on content with overflow handling
- Sequential Snapping: Option to disable velocity-based snapping for controlled navigation

Component Tokens

You can style the Drawer component using the following tokens:



Behavior

Slide Animation

- Direction Control: Drawers slide in from the specified edge (top, bottom, left, right)
- Smooth Transitions: Built-in spring animations for opening and closing
- Gesture Support: Drag to open/close with velocity-based snapping
- Snap Points: Multiple stopping positions for flexible sizing

State Management

- Controlled Mode: Use open and onOpenChange props for external state control
- Uncontrolled Mode: Component manages its own open/closed state internally
- Nested Support: Multiple drawers can be stacked for complex navigation

Mobile Behavior

- Responsive Positioning: Custom mobile offsets for optimal mobile experience
- Touch Gestures: Full gesture support for drag-to-open and drag-to-close
- Safe Areas: Respects mobile safe areas and notches
- Content Adaptation: Automatic sizing adjustments for mobile viewports

Content Management

- Flexible Layout: Modular header, body, and footer components
- Scrollable Content: Body content scrolls when exceeding drawer height
- Overflow Control: Configurable overflow behavior for different content types
- Dynamic Sizing: Content-driven height with maximum constraints

Accessibility

- Focus Management: Focus is trapped within drawer when open and restored on close
- Keyboard Navigation: Full keyboard support with Tab, Shift+Tab, and Escape keys
- Screen Reader Support: Proper ARIA roles, labels, and live regions
- ARIA Compliance: Uses appropriate dialog semantics and state announcements
- High Contrast: Supports high contrast mode and custom color schemes
- Motion Preferences: Respects user's reduced motion preferences for animations

Best Practices

When to Use Drawers

- Navigation Menus: For slide-out navigation that doesn't interrupt main content
- Detail Views: For displaying additional information without page navigation
- Form Dialogs: For forms that need more space than traditional modals
- Filter Panels: For advanced filtering options that need persistent visibility

Drawer Design Guidelines

- Always Use Portal: Always wrap DrawerContent with DrawerPortal and include DrawerOverlay for proper full-screen rendering
- Clear Purpose: Each drawer should have a focused, single purpose
- Appropriate Direction: Choose slide direction based on content type and screen size
- Consistent Behavior: Use consistent slide directions throughout your application
- Content Organization: Structure content with clear headers and logical sections

Content Guidelines

- Scannable Layout: Organize content with clear hierarchy and spacing
- Action Placement: Place primary actions in footer for easy access
- Scroll Indicators: Provide visual cues when content extends beyond visible area
- Loading States: Show loading states for dynamic content

Mobile Considerations

- Touch Targets: Ensure interactive elements meet minimum touch target sizes
- Gesture Conflicts: Avoid gesture conflicts with system navigation
- Safe Areas: Consider mobile safe areas and keyboard interactions
- Performance: Optimize animations and content loading for mobile devices

Features

- Dual Input System: Combined text input and dropdown selection in one component
- Flexible Positioning: Dropdown can be positioned on left or right side
- Responsive Design: Adaptive layout with floating labels on mobile for large size
- Integrated SingleSelect: Uses SingleSelect component for dropdown functionality
- Dynamic Spacing: Automatic padding adjustment based on dropdown and slot content
- Validation States: Built-in error styling with custom error messages
- Form Integration: Native HTML input attributes and form compatibility
- Accessibility: Full keyboard navigation and screen reader support

Responsive Layout

- Large Size on Mobile: Floating label animation for enhanced mobile experience
- Dynamic Padding: Automatic adjustment based on dropdown and slot positions
- Touch Optimization: Enhanced mobile interactions for both input and dropdown

Dropdown Integration

- SingleSelect Component: Uses internal SingleSelect for dropdown functionality
- NO_CONTAINER Variant: Seamless integration with minimal visual separation
- Inline Mode: Dropdown rendered inline with input field
- Alignment Control: Precise positioning relative to input boundaries

State Coordination

- Independent Controls: Input and dropdown maintain separate values and callbacks
- Coordinated Focus: Proper focus management between input and dropdown
- Error Handling: Unified error state affects both input and dropdown styling
- Disabled State: Disabling affects both components consistently

Dynamic Spacing

- Width Calculation: Automatic measurement of dropdown width for padding adjustment
- Gap Management: Consistent spacing between input content and dropdown
- Position Adaptation: Padding adjusts based on left or right dropdown positioning

Best Practices

When to Use DropdownInput

- Currency Inputs: Amount entry with currency selection
- Unit Values: Measurements with unit selection (px, rem, %, etc.)
- Phone Numbers: Number entry with country code selection
- Prefixed/Suffixed Data: Any input requiring both text and categorical selection

Dropdown Item Structure

- Clear Labels: Use descriptive labels that are easy to scan
- Logical Grouping: Group related items together with clear group names
- Consistent Formatting: Maintain consistent label format across items
- Appropriate Icons: Use icons or symbols when they add clarity

Position Selection

- Left Position: Use for prefixes like country codes, protocols, or categories
- Right Position: Use for suffixes like currencies, units, or file extensions
- User Expectations: Follow conventional patterns for your domain

Form Integration

- Controlled Components: Always use controlled inputs with proper state management
- Validation: Validate both input value and dropdown selection
- Error Messages: Provide clear error messages for validation failures
- Required Fields: Clearly indicate when both input and dropdown are required

Accessibility Considerations

- Label Association: Ensure proper labeling for both input and dropdown
- Keyboard Navigation: Test tab order and arrow key navigation
- Screen Readers: Verify that both components are properly announced
- Focus Indicators: Maintain visible focus indicators for keyboard users

Performance Optimization

- Item Lists: Optimize large dropdown item lists with appropriate grouping
- State Updates: Debounce input changes if triggering expensive operations
- Memory Management: Properly clean up event listeners and refs
- Render Optimization: Use React.memo for dropdown items if needed

Features

- Flexible Positioning: 4 sides and 3 alignment options for optimal placement
- Grouped Items: Organize menu items into labeled groups with optional separators
- Search Functionality: Built-in search to filter menu items by label
- Multiple Content Slots: 4 content slots per item for icons, badges, and additional content
- Action Variants: Special styling for primary and danger actions
- Submenu Support: Nested menu items for hierarchical navigation
- Controlled/Uncontrolled: Support for both controlled and uncontrolled open states
- Modal Mode: Renders as modal on mobile devices for better UX
- Collision Detection: Automatic repositioning to stay within viewport
- Disabled States: Individual menu items can be disabled
- Custom Sizing: Configurable width and height constraints
- Accessibility First: Full keyboard navigation and screen reader support

Usage Examples

Basic Action Menu

Simple menu with common actions



Menu with Search

Grouped Menu with Separators

Mobile Modal Menu

Menu with Status Items

Menu items with additional status information



Component Tokens

You can style the Menu component using the following tokens:



Behavior

Positioning Logic

- Side: Menu appears on specified side of trigger (top, right, bottom, left)
- Alignment: Menu aligns to start, center, or end of trigger
- Collision Detection: Automatically repositions if menu would overflow viewport
- Offsets: Fine-tune positioning with side and align offsets

Search Functionality

- Live Filtering: Menu items filter as user types
- Label Matching: Searches both main label and subLabel text
- Case Insensitive: Search is not case sensitive
- Group Filtering: Empty groups are hidden when all items are filtered out

Interaction Patterns

- Click to Open: Trigger click opens the menu
- Click Outside: Clicking outside closes the menu
- Escape Key: Escape key closes the menu
- Item Selection: Clicking menu item executes action and closes menu

Mobile Behavior

- Modal Mode: When asModal={true}, renders as full-screen modal on mobile
- Touch Interactions: Optimized for touch interactions
- Responsive Sizing: Adapts to screen size constraints

Accessibility

- Keyboard Navigation: Full keyboard support with arrow keys, Enter, and Escape
- Focus Management: Proper focus management when opening/closing menu
- Screen Reader Support: ARIA labels and proper semantic structure
- ARIA Compliance: Uses aria-expanded, aria-haspopup, and role attributes
- High Contrast: Supports high contrast mode and custom color schemes
- Tab Navigation: Proper tab order through menu items

Enums

MenuAlignment



MenuSide



MenuItemV2Variant



MenuItemV2ActionType



Best Practices

Menu Organization

- Group Related Items: Use groups to organize related functionality
- Logical Order: Place most common actions at the top
- Dangerous Actions: Use danger action type for destructive actions
- Clear Labels: Use descriptive labels that clearly indicate the action

Search Implementation

- Enable for Long Lists: Use search when menu has many items
- Meaningful Placeholder: Provide helpful search placeholder text
- Consider Performance: Search filters client-side, suitable for moderate lists

Positioning Guidelines

- Consider Context: Choose side and alignment based on trigger position
- Avoid Overflow: Ensure menu doesn't extend beyond viewport
- Mobile Considerations: Use modal mode for complex menus on mobile

Behavior

Modal Lifecycle

- Open Animation: Smooth fade-in animation for backdrop and modal content
- Close Animation: Fade-out animation when closing
- Scroll Lock: Body scroll is locked when modal is open
- Focus Management: Focus is trapped within the modal

Interaction Patterns

- Backdrop Click: Configurable backdrop click-to-close behavior
- Escape Key: Escape key closes the modal by default
- Close Button: Optional X button in header for closing
- Action Buttons: Primary and secondary actions in footer

Mobile Behavior

- Responsive Layout: Adapts to smaller screens automatically
- Drawer Mode: Optional drawer-style presentation on mobile
- Touch Interactions: Optimized for touch interactions
- Safe Areas: Respects mobile safe areas and notches

Content Management

- Scrollable Content: Content area scrolls when content exceeds viewport
- Header Pinning: Header stays fixed when content scrolls
- Footer Pinning: Footer stays fixed at bottom
- Responsive Sizing: Modal adapts to content size with constraints

Accessibility

- Focus Management: Focus is trapped within modal and restored on close
- Keyboard Navigation: Full keyboard support with Tab, Shift+Tab, and Escape
- Screen Reader Support: Proper ARIA roles, labels, and live regions
- ARIA Compliance: Uses role="dialog", aria-modal, and aria-labelledby
- High Contrast: Supports high contrast mode and custom color schemes
- Motion Preferences: Respects user's reduced motion preferences

Best Practices

When to Use Modals

- Important Decisions: For critical actions that need user confirmation
- Form Dialogs: For forms that interrupt the main workflow
- Information Display: For detailed information that needs focus
- Error Messages: For critical error messages that need attention

Modal Design Guidelines

- Clear Purpose: Modal should have a clear, single purpose
- Concise Content: Keep content focused and concise
- Clear Actions: Action buttons should clearly indicate what will happen
- Escape Routes: Always provide a way to close the modal

Mobile Considerations

- Use Drawer Mode: Enable drawer mode for better mobile experience
- Touch Targets: Ensure buttons are large enough for touch interaction
- Content Length: Keep content length appropriate for mobile screens
- Safe Areas: Consider mobile safe areas when positioning content

Action Button Guidelines

- Primary Action: Use for the main action user should take
- Secondary Action: Use for alternative or cancel actions
- Dangerous Actions: Use danger button type for destructive actions
- Loading States: Show loading state for async operations

Behavior

Selection Management

- Multiple Selection: Users can select multiple options using checkboxes
- Selection Feedback: Visual feedback shows selected items with checkmarks
- Clear Functionality: Clear button removes all selections when visible
- Selection Display: Shows count or text based on selectionTagType setting

Search Behavior

- Live Filtering: Search filters options in real-time as user types
- Label and SubLabel: Searches both main label and subLabel text
- Case Insensitive: Search is not case sensitive
- Group Filtering: Groups with no matching items are hidden

Keyboard Navigation

- Arrow Keys: Navigate through menu options
- Space/Enter: Toggle selection of the currently focused option
- Escape: Close the dropdown menu
- Type Ahead: Jump to options by typing first letters

Positioning Logic

- Auto-Positioning: Dropdown repositions to stay within viewport
- Side Options: Can appear on top, bottom, left, or right of trigger
- Alignment Control: Align to start, center, or end of trigger
- Offset Adjustments: Fine-tune positioning with pixel offsets

Mobile Behavior

Design Guidelines

- Appropriate Sizing: Choose size based on interface density and importance
- Selection Feedback: Ensure users can clearly see what they've selected

Content Guidelines

- Concise Options: Keep option labels brief but descriptive
- Helpful SubLabels: Use subLabels to provide additional context when needed
- Logical Ordering: Order options logically (alphabetical, by frequency, or importance)
- Search Support: Enable search for lists with many options

Mobile Considerations

- Drawer Mode: Use drawer mode on mobile for better touch experience
- Touch Targets: Ensure adequate touch target sizes for mobile devices
- Search Functionality: Enable search for long option lists on mobile
- Performance: Consider lazy loading for very large option sets

Keyboard Interactions

- Enter Key: Adds the current input value as a new tag
- Backspace Key: When input is empty, removes the last tag
- Tab Navigation: Standard tab order through tags and input
- Focus Management: Clicking container focuses the input field

Tag Management

- Duplicate Prevention: Automatically prevents adding existing tags
- Trim Whitespace: Input values are automatically trimmed

Visual Feedback

When to Use MultiValueInput

- Contact Lists: Email addresses, usernames, or contact identifiers
- Filtering: Multiple filter criteria or search terms
- Configuration: Multiple values for settings or preferences

Input Validation

- Format Validation: Validate input format before adding tags
- Length Limits: Implement reasonable limits for individual tags and total count
- Custom Processing: Transform input values (capitalize, format, etc.)
- Duplicate Handling: Decide whether to allow or prevent duplicates
- Error Feedback: Provide clear validation messages

User Experience

- Clear Instructions: Use hint text to explain interaction patterns
- Visual Cues: Make tag removal actions clearly visible
- Keyboard Shortcuts: Ensure Enter and Backspace work as expected
- Placeholder Text: Provide helpful placeholder text for context
- Size Selection: Choose appropriate size for form context

Data Management

- State Structure: Use arrays for simple strings, objects for complex data
- Persistence: Save tag state appropriately for form submission
- Performance: Consider virtualization for very large tag lists
- Accessibility: Ensure screen readers can understand tag structure

Accessibility Considerations

- Label Association: Proper labeling for screen readers
- Tag Announcement: Ensure tags are announced when added/removed
- Keyboard Navigation: Full keyboard accessibility for all interactions
- Focus Indicators: Visible focus indicators for keyboard users
- Error Communication: Clear error messages for validation failures

Integration Patterns

- Validation: Integrate with form validation libraries
- Autocomplete: Combine with suggestion systems for better UX
- Data Sources: Connect to APIs or static data for validation/formatting
- State Management: Use with Redux, Zustand, or other state libraries

Features

- Stepper Controls: Built-in increment/decrement buttons with triangle indicators

- Min/Max Constraints: Automatic validation and button disabling at limits
- Step Intervals: Configurable step size for increment/decrement operations
- Responsive Design: Adaptive layout with floating labels on mobile for large size
- Visual Controls: Intuitive up/down arrow buttons positioned on the right
- Keyboard Support: Standard numeric input keyboard interactions
- Validation States: Built-in error styling with custom error messages
- Form Integration: Native HTML input attributes and form compatibility
- Accessibility: Full keyboard navigation and screen reader support

Usage Examples

Behavior

Stepper Controls

- Increment Button: Increases value by step amount (top arrow)
- Decrement Button: Decreases value by step amount (bottom arrow)
- Auto-disable: Buttons disable when reaching min/max limits
- Visual Feedback: Hover and focus states for better interaction
- Click Handling: Triggers onChange with synthetic events

Value Management

- Undefined Values: Supports undefined for empty states
- Number Parsing: Automatic conversion from string to number
- Step Validation: Ensures increments follow step intervals
- Boundary Checking: Prevents values outside min/max range
- Decimal Support: Handles decimal values with proper precision

Responsive Layout

- Large Size on Mobile: Floating label animation for enhanced mobile experience
- Dynamic Spacing: Automatic adjustment of stepper button positioning
- Touch Optimization: Enhanced mobile interactions for stepper controls
- Consistent Styling: Maintains visual consistency across screen sizes

Keyboard Interactions

- Arrow Keys: Native browser support for up/down arrow increment/decrement
- Direct Input: Standard numeric keyboard input
- Tab Navigation: Proper tab order through input and stepper controls
- Focus Management: Clear focus indicators for accessibility

Best Practices

When to Use NumberInput

- Quantity Selection: Product quantities, item counts, etc.
- Numeric Settings: Configuration values, limits, thresholds
- Measurements: Dimensions, weights, temperatures, percentages
- Financial Inputs: Prices, amounts, budgets (with appropriate step values)
- Range Inputs: Values within specific numeric ranges

Value Handling

- Type Safety: Use proper TypeScript types (number | undefined)
- Validation: Implement client-side validation for business rules
- Error Handling: Provide clear error messages for invalid values
- Default Values: Consider appropriate default values for better UX
- Precision: Use appropriate step values for decimal precision

Min/Max Configuration

- Logical Ranges: Set realistic min/max values for your use case
- User Feedback: Clearly communicate value constraints
- Progressive Enhancement: Allow manual typing beyond stepper limits
- Edge Cases: Handle edge cases like negative numbers appropriately

Step Configuration

- Appropriate Increments: Choose step values that make sense for your data
- Decimal Precision: Use decimal steps (0.01, 0.1) for precise values
- User Expectations: Match step values to user mental models
- Performance: Consider reasonable step sizes for good UX

Accessibility Considerations

- Label Association: Ensure proper labeling for screen readers
- Stepper Announcement: Verify stepper controls are accessible
- Keyboard Navigation: Test all keyboard interactions
- Value Changes: Ensure value changes are announced appropriately
- Error Communication: Provide clear, accessible error messages

Form Integration

- Controlled Components: Always use controlled inputs with proper state
- Validation Libraries: Compatible with React Hook Form, Formik, etc.
- Submission Handling: Handle undefined values appropriately in forms
- Reset Functionality: Implement proper form reset behavior
- Loading States: Consider loading states for async operations

Performance Optimization

- Debouncing: Consider debouncing for expensive validation operations
- State Management: Use appropriate state management patterns
- Re-rendering: Optimize for minimal unnecessary re-renders
- Memory Cleanup: Properly clean up event listeners and timers

You can style the OTPInput component using the following tokens:



The component uses responsive tokens that adapt to different breakpoints with consistent styling for optimal user experience across devices.

Features

- Individual Digit Inputs: Separate input field for each OTP digit
- Auto-Focus Management: Automatic focus progression and regression
- Keyboard Navigation: Arrow key navigation between inputs
- Clipboard Support: Smart paste functionality with digit extraction
- Numeric Validation: Only accepts numeric digits (0-9)
- Customizable Length: Configurable number of digits (typically 4-8)
- Error States: Visual error feedback for invalid codes
- Accessibility: Full keyboard navigation and screen reader support
- Form Integration: Compatible with form libraries and validation
- Auto-Focus: Optional auto-focus on component mount

Usage Examples

Basic OTP Input

Simple 6-digit OTP input for verification:



SMS Authentication

4-digit SMS OTP with custom validation:



Two-Factor Authentication

8-digit 2FA code with security context:



Email Verification

6-digit email verification with resend functionality:



Custom Length OTP

Variable length OTP based on security requirements:



Behavior

Focus Management

- Auto-Focus: Optionally focuses first input on mount
- Forward Focus: Automatically moves to next input when digit is entered
- Backward Focus: Moves to previous input on backspace when current is empty
- Arrow Navigation: Left/right arrow keys move between inputs
- Click Focus: Clicking any input focuses that specific field

Input Handling

- Numeric Only: Accepts only digits (0-9), ignores other characters
- Single Digit: Each input accepts only one digit, replacing existing
- Backspace Logic: Clears current digit or moves to previous input
- Overflow Handling: Extra characters are ignored, maintains single digit per input

Clipboard Support

- Smart Paste: Paste operation on first input distributes digits across all inputs
- Digit Extraction: Automatically extracts numeric digits from pasted content
- Length Limiting: Only uses digits up to the specified length
- Focus Positioning: Focuses appropriate input after paste operation

State Synchronization

- Value Binding: Component value stays synchronized with parent state
- Change Callbacks: Calls onChange for every digit modification
- Error Propagation: Error state applies to all input fields
- Disabled State: Disabling affects all inputs uniformly

Best Practices

When to Use OTPInput

- Email Verification: Confirm email addresses during registration
- SMS Authentication: Phone number verification workflows
- Two-Factor Authentication: Secondary authentication step
- Password Reset: Secure password reset verification
- Transaction Confirmation: High-security transaction verification

Security Considerations

- Time Limits: Implement appropriate code expiration times
- Rate Limiting: Prevent brute force attacks with rate limiting
- Secure Transmission: Always use HTTPS for OTP transmission
- Auto-Clear: Clear codes after successful verification
- Attempt Limits: Limit the number of verification attempts

User Experience

- Clear Instructions: Provide clear context about where the code is sent
- Visual Feedback: Show loading states during verification
- Error Handling: Provide specific, actionable error messages
- Resend Options: Offer code resend functionality with appropriate delays
- Auto-Submit: Consider auto-submitting when code is complete

Length Configuration

- 4 Digits: Quick SMS verification, lower security scenarios
- 6 Digits: Standard email verification, moderate security
- 8 Digits: High-security scenarios, sensitive operations
- Custom Length: Match your backend OTP generation settings

Accessibility Considerations

- Label Association: Ensure proper labeling for screen readers
- Input Announcement: Verify each input is properly announced
- Keyboard Navigation: Test all keyboard interactions thoroughly
- Focus Indicators: Maintain visible focus indicators
- Error Communication: Ensure error messages are accessible

Form Integration

- Controlled Components: Always use controlled inputs with proper state
- Validation: Integrate with form validation libraries
- Submission: Handle form submission when OTP is complete
- Reset Functionality: Implement proper form reset behavior
- Loading States: Show appropriate loading states during verification

Performance Optimization

- Debouncing: Consider debouncing for expensive validation operations
- Memoization: Use React.memo for input optimization if needed
- State Management: Use appropriate state management patterns
- Memory Cleanup: Properly clean up timers and event listeners

Error Handling

- Validation Timing: Validate only when OTP is complete
- Clear Messaging: Provide specific error messages for different scenarios
- Recovery: Allow easy recovery from error states
- Visual Feedback: Use consistent error styling across all inputs

- Screen Real Estate: Choose appropriate sizes for mobile layouts

Component Tokens

You can style the Radio component using the following tokens:



Behavior

Selection Behavior

- Mutual Exclusivity: Only one radio button can be selected within a group
- Group Management: RadioGroup automatically manages selection state
- Value Tracking: Selected value is tracked and propagated through onChange callbacks
- Default Selection: Support for default selected values in uncontrolled mode

Keyboard Navigation

- Arrow Keys: Navigate between radio buttons within a group
- Auto-Selection: Arrow key navigation automatically selects the focused radio
- Tab Behavior: Tab moves focus between radio groups, not individual radios
- Space/Enter: Activates the currently focused radio button

State Management

- Controlled Mode: External state management with value and onChange props
- Uncontrolled Mode: Internal state management with defaultValue prop
- Individual Controls: Can be used standalone outside of groups
- Validation Support: Built-in support for required and error states

Focus Management

- Group Focus: Only the selected radio (or first radio) in a group is focusable
- Focus Indicators: Clear visual focus indicators for keyboard users
- Focus Restoration: Focus is properly managed during dynamic updates
- Skip Navigation: Proper tab order through radio groups

Content Management

- Label Association: Proper label association with radio inputs
- Subtext Support: Optional descriptive text below main labels
- Slot Content: Support for additional content like badges or icons
- Required Indicators: Automatic asterisk display for required fields

Accessibility

- ARIA Compliance: Uses proper role="radiogroup" and aria-checked attributes
- Keyboard Navigation: Full keyboard support with arrow keys for navigation
- Screen Reader Support: Proper announcements of state changes and group structure
- Focus Management: Focus is trapped within radio groups during navigation
- Label Association: Each radio is properly associated with its label
- Group Semantics: Radio groups are announced as groups to screen readers
- State Communication: Current selection and states are communicated to assistive technologies
- Required Field Support: Required fields are announced to screen readers
- Error State Support: Error states are communicated through ARIA attributes

When to Use Radio Buttons

- Mutually Exclusive Choices: When users must select exactly one option from a list
- Visible Options: When all options should be visible at once (typically 2-7 options)
- Single Selection: When only one choice is allowed, unlike checkboxes
- Form Controls: As part of forms where a selection is required

Radio Group Design Guidelines

- Clear Labels: Use descriptive labels that clearly explain each option
- Logical Ordering: Order options logically (alphabetical, by importance, or frequency)
- Default Selection: Consider providing a sensible default selection
- Group Related Options: Keep related radio buttons together in groups

Content Guidelines

- Concise Labels: Keep radio button labels brief but descriptive
- Helpful Subtext: Use subtext to provide additional context when needed
- Consistent Formatting: Maintain consistent label and subtext formatting
- Clear Hierarchy: Use typography and spacing to establish clear content hierarchy

Form Integration

- Validation: Implement proper validation for required radio groups
- Error Messaging: Provide clear error messages for validation failures
- Default Values: Set appropriate default values for better user experience
- State Persistence: Consider persisting selections during form interactions

Behavior

Selection Behavior

- Single Selection: Only one option can be selected at a time
- Value Management: Selected value is controlled through props
- Callback Execution: onSelect callback fires when selection changes
- Auto-Close: Dropdown automatically closes after selection

Search Behavior

- Live Filtering: Search filters options in real-time as user types
- Label and SubLabel: Searches both main label and subLabel text
- Case Insensitive: Search is not case sensitive
- Group Filtering: Groups with no matching items are hidden

Keyboard Navigation

- Arrow Keys: Navigate through menu options
- Enter/Space: Select the currently focused option
- Escape: Close the dropdown menu
- Type Ahead: Jump to options by typing first letters

Positioning Logic

- Auto-Positioning: Dropdown repositions to stay within viewport
- Side Options: Can appear on top, bottom, left, or right of trigger
- Alignment Control: Align to start, center, or end of trigger
- Offset Adjustments: Fine-tune positioning with pixel offsets

Mobile Behavior

- Drawer Mode: Renders as drawer on mobile devices when useDrawerOnMobile is true
- Touch Optimization: Optimized for touch interactions
- Responsive Sizing: Adapts to mobile screen constraints

Error State Management

- Visual Indicators: Error styling applied to trigger and labels
- Error Messages: Displays error message below the field
- State Synchronization: Error state clears when valid selection is made

Focus Management

- Trigger Focus: Focus is managed on the trigger element
- Menu Focus: Focus moves through menu items during navigation
- Focus Restoration: Focus returns to trigger when menu closes
- Focus Events: onFocus and onBlur callbacks for external focus management

Accessibility

- ARIA Compliance: Full ARIA support with role="combobox", aria-expanded, and aria-haspopup
- Keyboard Navigation: Complete keyboard support with arrow keys, Enter, Escape, and Tab
- Screen Reader Support: Proper announcements for state changes and selections
- Focus Management: Focus is trapped within dropdown and restored properly
- Label Association: Form labels are properly associated with the select trigger
- Group Semantics: Menu groups are announced as groups to screen readers
- Search Accessibility: Search functionality is accessible with proper ARIA attributes
- Error Communication: Error states are communicated through ARIA attributes
- Required Field Support: Required fields are announced to assistive technologies

Best Practices

When to Use SingleSelect

- Option Selection: When users need to choose one option from multiple choices
- Form Fields: As form controls where a specific selection is required
- Settings: For configuration options and preferences
- Data Filtering: For filtering or sorting data based on categories

Design Guidelines

- Clear Labels: Use descriptive labels that clearly explain the purpose
- Logical Grouping: Group related options together with meaningful group labels
- Appropriate Sizing: Choose size based on interface density and importance
- Consistent Patterns: Use consistent selection patterns throughout your application

Content Guidelines

- Concise Options: Keep option labels brief but descriptive
- Helpful SubLabels: Use subLabels to provide additional context when needed
- Logical Ordering: Order options logically (alphabetical, by frequency, or importance)
- Search Support: Enable search for lists with many options

Form Integration

- Validation: Implement proper validation with clear error messages
- Required Fields: Mark required fields clearly with asterisks
- Help Text: Provide contextual help when selection criteria may be unclear
- Default Values: Consider providing sensible default selections when appropriate

Mobile Considerations

- Drawer Mode: Use drawer mode on mobile for better touch experience
- Touch Targets: Ensure adequate touch target sizes for mobile devices
- Search Functionality: Enable search for long option lists on mobile
- Performance: Consider lazy loading for very large option sets

Behavior

Value Management

- Controlled Mode: Use value and onValueChange props for external state control
- Uncontrolled Mode: Use defaultValue for component-managed state
- Multi-thumb: Array values create multiple thumbs for range selection
- Value Constraints: Values are automatically constrained to min/max bounds

Interaction Patterns

- Thumb Dragging: Click and drag thumbs to adjust values
- Track Clicking: Click on track to jump thumb to that position
- Keyboard Navigation: Arrow keys for precise value adjustment
- Touch Support: Optimized touch interactions for mobile devices

Formatting System

- Type-based: Different formatting based on SliderValueType
- Custom Formatters: Use custom functions for complex formatting
- Prefix/Suffix: Add text before or after values
- Precision Control: Configurable decimal places for display

Accessibility Features

- Keyboard Navigation: Full keyboard support with arrow keys, Page Up/Down, Home/End
- ARIA Labels: Proper ARIA roles and labels for screen readers
- Focus Management: Clear focus indicators and logical tab order
- Value Announcements: Screen reader announcements for value changes

Best Practices

When to Use Sliders

- Range Selection: For selecting values within a continuous range
- Settings Adjustment: For adjusting settings like volume, brightness, or opacity
- Filtering: For range-based filtering in search or data views
- Quantity Selection: For selecting quantities with clear min/max bounds

Slider Design Guidelines

- Clear Labels: Always provide clear labels indicating what the slider controls
- Appropriate Ranges: Choose meaningful min/max values and step increments
- Value Feedback: Show current values either in labels or through formatting
- Consistent Sizing: Use consistent slider sizes throughout your application

Value Formatting

- Meaningful Units: Use appropriate units (%, $, C) that users understand
- Precision Levels: Match decimal precision to the use case (whole numbers vs decimals)
- Custom Formatters: Use custom formatters for complex business logic
- Visual Feedback: Consider showing formatted values in real-time

Accessibility Considerations

- Keyboard Support: Ensure all functionality is available via keyboard
- Screen Readers: Test with screen readers to verify announcements
- Color Independence: Don't rely solely on color to convey state
- Touch Targets: Ensure thumb areas are large enough for touch interaction

Mobile Considerations

- Touch Targets: Ensure thumbs are large enough for accurate touch interaction
- Gesture Support: Test drag gestures on various mobile devices
- Orientation: Consider how sliders work in both portrait and landscape modes
- Performance: Optimize for smooth animations on lower-powered devices

Component Tokens

You can style the TextArea component using the following tokens:



The component uses responsive tokens that adapt to different breakpoints with floating labels on small screens and consistent styling across all states.

Features

- Multi-line Input: Configurable rows and columns for text area sizing
- Responsive Labels: Floating labels on small screens, standard labels on larger screens
- Resize Control: Customizable resize behavior (none, vertical, horizontal, both)
- Error States: Visual error feedback with custom error messages
- Form Integration: Full form library support with validation
- Accessibility: Screen reader support and proper focus management
- Helper Text: Support for hint text and help icon tooltips
- Character Counting: Can be extended with character count functionality
- Auto-Focus: Optional auto-focus on component mount
- Disabled State: Complete disabled state styling and behavior

Usage Examples

Basic Description Field

Simple textarea for user descriptions:



Comment Box

Textarea for user comments with validation:



Feedback Form

Large textarea for detailed feedback:



Message Composer

Resizable textarea for message composition:



Code Snippet Input

Textarea for code or technical content:



Article Content

Large textarea for article or blog content:



Support Ticket

Textarea for customer support requests:



Behavior

Responsive Labels

- Large Screens: Labels appear above the textarea with sublabels
- Small Screens: Labels float inside the textarea and scale when focused or filled
- Focus Animation: Smooth transition for floating label positioning
- Label Scaling: Floating labels scale down when active

Resize Functionality

- None: No resize handle, fixed size
- Vertical: Only vertical resizing allowed
- Horizontal: Only horizontal resizing allowed
- Both: Both directions resizable
- Block/Inline: CSS logical properties for resize direction

Focus and Validation

- Focus States: Visual focus indicators with border and shadow changes
- Error States: Red borders and error message display
- Validation: Real-time validation support with error feedback
- Required Fields: Visual indicators for required fields

Padding Adjustments

- Dynamic Padding: Adjusts top/bottom padding on small screens for floating labels
- Consistent Spacing: Maintains consistent internal spacing across breakpoints
- Content Alignment: Proper text alignment with floating label positioning

Best Practices

When to Use TextArea

- Long-form Content: Comments, descriptions, articles, messages
- Multi-line Input: Address fields, feedback forms, code snippets
- Flexible Content: When content length is unpredictable
- Rich Text Needs: Before implementing rich text editors
- Form Fields: Any form requiring more than a single line of text

Sizing Guidelines

- 3-4 Rows: Short descriptions, comments, brief feedback
- 5-6 Rows: Medium content like detailed descriptions, messages
- 8+ Rows: Long-form content like articles, documentation
- Resize Options: Allow vertical resize for user flexibility
- Character Limits: Implement and display character count when needed

Accessibility Considerations

- Label Association: Ensure proper label-textarea association
- Error Announcements: Make error states accessible to screen readers
- Focus Management: Maintain clear focus indicators
- Keyboard Navigation: Support all standard keyboard interactions
- Help Text: Provide clear instructions and help text

Form Integration

- Controlled Components: Always use controlled components with proper state
- Validation: Integrate with form validation libraries
- Error Handling: Provide specific, actionable error messages
- Auto-save: Consider implementing draft saving for long forms
- Character Counting: Show character/word count for length-limited fields

Performance Optimization

- Debouncing: Debounce onChange for expensive operations
- Auto-save: Implement debounced auto-save for long content
- Memory Management: Clean up event listeners and timers
- State Management: Use appropriate state management patterns
- Memoization: Consider memoizing for complex validation logic

User Experience

- Clear Placeholders: Use descriptive placeholder text
- Progressive Enhancement: Start with basic functionality
- Auto-resize: Consider auto-expanding textarea based on content
- Save Indicators: Show save status for important content
- Format Preservation: Maintain formatting when appropriate

Content Guidelines

- Character Limits: Set reasonable limits and communicate them clearly
- Validation Messages: Provide helpful, specific error messages
- Formatting Support: Consider markdown or rich text for complex content
- Preview Options: Offer preview functionality for formatted content
- Content Recovery: Implement draft recovery for important forms

Security Considerations

- Input Sanitization: Sanitize user input on the backend
- XSS Prevention: Prevent cross-site scripting attacks
- Content Validation: Validate content length and format
- Rate Limiting: Implement rate limiting for form submissions
- CSRF Protection: Use CSRF tokens for form submissions

Component Tokens

You can style the TextInput component using the following tokens:



The component uses responsive tokens that adapt to different breakpoints:

- sm: Mobile-optimized with floating label behavior for large size
- lg: Desktop layout with consistent behavior across all sizes

Features

- Responsive Design: Adaptive layout with floating labels on mobile for large size
- Flexible Slots: Left and right slots for icons, buttons, or custom content
- Validation States: Built-in error styling with custom error messages
- Accessibility: Full keyboard navigation and screen reader support
- Form Integration: Native HTML input attributes and form compatibility
- Visual States: Hover, focus, and disabled states with smooth transitions
- Customizable Sizing: Three size variants for different layout needs
- Helper Text: Support for hints, help icons, and error messages
- Dynamic Padding: Automatic padding adjustment based on slot content

Usage Examples

Basic Input

Simple text input with label and hint text:



Input with Error State

Text input showing validation error:



Input with Slots

Text input with icon slots for enhanced UX:



Behavior

Responsive Floating Labels

- Large Size on Mobile: Automatically shows floating label animation
- Label Positioning: Smooth transition between placeholder and floating states
- Touch Optimization: Enhanced mobile experience with larger touch targets

Focus Management

- Focus States: Visual feedback with outline and shadow changes
- Keyboard Navigation: Full tab navigation support
- Focus Callbacks: Custom onFocus and onBlur handlers

Dynamic Layout

- Slot Integration: Automatic padding adjustment for left/right content
- Width Calculation: Dynamic measurement of slot content for precise spacing
- Responsive Tokens: Breakpoint-aware styling and spacing

Validation Integration

- Error Styling: Automatic error state styling when error prop is true
- Message Display: Error messages shown below input with proper styling
- State Consistency: Visual state matches validation state throughout interaction

Best Practices

When to Use TextInput

- Form Fields: Primary choice for text-based form inputs
- Search Interfaces: With appropriate left slot icons
- Data Entry: For capturing user information and content
- Settings Panels: For configurable text values

Label and Hint Guidelines

- Clear Labels: Use descriptive labels that explain the expected input
- Helpful Hints: Provide context or format examples in hint text
- Error Messages: Write specific, actionable error messages
- Required Indication: Use required prop and clear visual indicators

Size Selection

- Small: Use in compact forms or secondary inputs
- Medium: Default choice for most form scenarios
- Large: Use for primary inputs or mobile-first experiences

Slot Usage

- Left Slots: Icons, currency symbols, or input prefixes
- Right Slots: Action buttons, validation icons, or suffixes
- Interactive Content: Ensure slot content has proper focus management
- Visual Balance: Keep slot content appropriately sized

Accessibility Considerations

- Label Association: Always provide labels for screen readers
- Error Announcement: Ensure error messages are announced to screen readers
- Focus Indicators: Maintain visible focus indicators for keyboard users
- Form Structure: Use proper form markup and validation patterns

Form Integration

- Controlled Components: Always use controlled inputs with value and onChange
- Validation Timing: Validate on blur for better user experience
- Form Libraries: Compatible with React Hook Form, Formik, and other libraries
- Submit Handling: Integrate with form submission and validation flows

Component Tokens

You can style the UnitInput component using the following tokens:



The component uses responsive tokens that adapt to different breakpoints with size-specific padding and consistent styling across all states.

Features

- Integrated Unit Display: Built-in unit label with configurable positioning
- Multiple Sizes: Medium and large size variants with responsive behavior
- Numeric Input: Number input type with min, max, and step validation
- Slot Support: Configurable left and right slots for icons or additional elements
- Responsive Labels: Floating labels on small screens for large size variant
- Error States: Visual error feedback with custom error messages
- Form Integration: Full form library support with validation
- Accessibility: Screen reader support and proper focus management
- Dynamic Padding: Automatically adjusts padding based on unit and slot positioning
- Default Icon: Includes Weight icon as default right slot

Usage Examples

Weight Input

Basic weight input with right-positioned unit:



Currency Input

Price input with left-positioned currency unit:

Behavior

Unit Positioning

- Right Position: Unit appears on the right side with gray background
- Left Position: Unit appears on the left side with gray background
- Border Integration: Unit has matching border styling with the input
- Dynamic Width: Unit container adjusts width based on content length

Size Variants

- Medium Size: Standard padding and font size for most use cases
- Large Size: Increased padding with floating labels on small screens
- Responsive Behavior: Large size shows floating labels on mobile devices
- Consistent Spacing: Maintains proper spacing regardless of size

Slot Management

- Left Slot: Positioned between left edge and input, adjusted for unit position
- Right Slot: Positioned between input and right edge, includes default Weight icon
- Dynamic Padding: Input padding automatically adjusts based on slot widths
- Icon Integration: Slots integrate seamlessly with unit positioning

Focus and Validation

- Focus States: Visual focus indicators with border and shadow changes
- Numeric Validation: Enforces numeric input with min, max, and step constraints
- Error Feedback: Red borders and error message display for invalid states
- Required Fields: Visual indicators for required form fields

Best Practices

When to Use UnitInput

- Measurements: Weight, height, distance, temperature, speed
- Quantities: Inventory counts, limits, quotas with units
- Financial: Prices, amounts, budgets with currency units
- Scientific: Laboratory measurements, calculations with units
- Configuration: Settings that require specific units or measurements

Unit Selection Guidelines

- Clear Units: Use widely recognized unit abbreviations (kg, cm, $, %)
- Consistent Units: Maintain unit consistency within related inputs
- Localization: Consider locale-specific units and formats
- Abbreviations: Keep unit text short to maintain clean appearance
- Context: Choose units appropriate for the target audience

Size and Layout

- Medium Size: Default choice for most form layouts
- Large Size: Use for prominent inputs or mobile-first designs
- Responsive Design: Test floating label behavior on small screens
- Form Consistency: Maintain consistent sizing within form groups
- Visual Hierarchy: Use size to indicate input importance

Accessibility Considerations

- Label Association: Ensure proper labeling including unit information
- Screen Readers: Unit information should be accessible to assistive technology
- Focus Management: Maintain clear focus indicators and keyboard navigation
- Error Communication: Make validation errors accessible and specific
- Help Text: Provide clear instructions about expected values and units

Validation and Error Handling

- Range Validation: Set appropriate min/max values for the context
- Step Validation: Use logical step values for the measurement type
- Unit Conversion: Consider providing unit conversion helpers
- Error Messages: Provide specific, actionable error messages
- Real-time Validation: Validate input as user types when appropriate

Form Integration

- Controlled Components: Always use controlled inputs with proper state management
- Data Types: Handle number/undefined types appropriately
- Submission: Convert and validate units before form submission
- Default Values: Provide sensible defaults when appropriate
- Reset Functionality: Implement proper form reset behavior

Performance Optimization

- State Management: Use appropriate state patterns for complex forms
- Debouncing: Consider debouncing for expensive validation operations
- Memory Management: Clean up event listeners and effects properly
- Render Optimization: Memoize expensive calculations and validations

User Experience

- Clear Placeholders: Use descriptive placeholder text
- Helpful Hints: Provide context about expected ranges and formats
- Progressive Enhancement: Start with basic functionality
- Visual Feedback: Show clear confirmation of successful input
- Error Recovery: Allow easy correction of invalid inputs

contributing.title: Contributing
contributing.description: Learn how to contribute to Blend Design System. Guidelines for open source contributors, developers, and designers.
contributing.content:
Contributing to Blend Design System

We welcome contributions from the community! Whether you're fixing bugs, adding new components, improving documentation, or proposing new features, your contributions help make Blend better for everyone.

Before You Start

Code of Conduct

Please read and follow our Code of Conduct. We're committed to maintaining a welcoming and inclusive community.

Getting Help

- GitHub Discussions: Ask questions and share ideas
- Issues: Report bugs and request features
- Discord: Join our community for real-time chat

Development Setup

Prerequisites

- Node.js 18+
- pnpm (recommended package manager)
- Git for version control
- Code Editor (VS Code recommended with ReScript extension)

Fork and Clone



Install Dependencies



Development Workflow



Project Structure

Understanding the monorepo structure:



Types of Contributions

 Bug Fixes

1. Check existing issues before creating new ones
2. Include reproduction steps and expected vs actual behavior
3. Add tests to prevent regression
4. Update documentation if needed

Example Bug Fix Process:



 New Components

Creating new components requires careful planning and implementation:

Component Structure



Component Template



ReScript Bindings



Requirements for New Components

- Accessibility: WCAG 2.1 AA compliance
- TypeScript: Full type definitions
- ReScript: Complete bindings
- Tests: Unit and integration tests
- Stories: Comprehensive Storybook stories
- Documentation: Usage examples and API reference

 Documentation

Documentation improvements are always welcome:

- Improve existing component documentation
- Add usage examples and best practices
- Update getting started guides
- Fix typos and improve clarity
- Add troubleshooting sections

 Design Tokens

When proposing design token changes:

1. Create an issue first to discuss the change
2. Ensure backward compatibility where possible
3. Update all affected components
4. Include design rationale and use cases
5. Test across all themes

Testing Requirements

Unit Tests

- Test all component variants and states
- Test accessibility features
- Test error boundaries and edge cases
- Maintain minimum 80% code coverage

Integration Tests

- Test component interactions
- Test theme switching
- Test responsive behavior

Visual Regression Tests

- Use Storybook for visual testing
- Test all component stories
- Include different themes and screen sizes

Running Tests



Documentation Standards

Component Documentation

Each component should include:

- API Reference: Complete prop documentation
- Usage Examples: Common use cases
- Accessibility: ARIA labels, keyboard navigation
- Do's and Don'ts: Best practices and anti-patterns
- Troubleshooting: Common issues and solutions

Code Comments

- Document complex logic and business rules
- Explain design decisions and trade-offs
- Include links to relevant design specifications
- Use JSDoc for public APIs

Submission Guidelines

Before Submitting

1. Ensure all tests pass: pnpm test
2. Run linting: pnpm lint
3. Check TypeScript: pnpm type-check
4. Update documentation if needed
5. Add changeset for versioning

Changeset Creation



Pull Request Guidelines

PR Title Format



PR Description Template



Review Process

1. Automated checks must pass
2. Design team review for UI changes
3. Code review by maintainers
4. Documentation review if applicable
5. Final approval and merge

Release Process

Semantic Versioning

We follow Semantic Versioning:

- Patch (1.0.1): Bug fixes
- Minor (1.1.0): New features, backward compatible
- Major (2.0.0): Breaking changes

Release Notes

Contributors are recognized in release notes:

- Bug fixes and improvements
- New features and components
- Breaking changes
- Special thanks to contributors

Community Recognition

Contributor Levels

- First-time Contributor: Welcome badge
- Regular Contributor: Community member badge
- Core Contributor: Maintainer consideration
- Maintainer: Repository access and responsibilities

Showcase

Projects using Blend are featured in our community showcase. Share your implementations to inspire others!

Troubleshooting

Common Development Issues

Build failures:



TypeScript errors:

- Check component exports in index.ts
- Verify type definitions are complete
- Ensure ReScript bindings match TypeScript interfaces

Test failures:

- Check for async operations in tests
- Verify mocks are properly configured
- Ensure clean test environment

Getting Unstuck

If you're stuck:

1. Check existing documentation and issues
2. Ask in GitHub Discussions
3. Join our Discord community
4. Reach out to maintainers

Resources

Development Tools

- Storybook: Component development and testing
- TypeScript: Type safety and IntelliSense
- ReScript: Functional programming support
- Jest: Testing framework
- ESLint: Code linting

Design Resources

- Figma: Design files and specifications
- Design Tokens: Token definitions and usage
- Accessibility: WCAG guidelines and tools

Learning Materials

- React: Component development
- TypeScript: Type system
- ReScript: Functional programming
- Testing: Best practices

Thank You

Thank you for contributing to Blend Design System! Your efforts help create better experiences for developers and users worldwide. Every contribution, no matter how small, makes a difference.

Welcome to the community!

getting-started.title: Getting Started
getting-started.description: Get started with Blend Design System. Learn installation, setup, and best practices for using our design system in your projects.
getting-started.content:
Getting Started with Blend Design System

Welcome to Blend Design System! This guide will help you get started with implementing Blend in your project, whether you're a team member or an open source contributor.

What is Blend?

Blend is a comprehensive design system that provides:

- React Components: Production-ready components with TypeScript support
- Design Tokens: Consistent design tokens for colors, typography, spacing, and more
- Figma Integration: Direct sync between Figma designs and code components

Installation

Choose your preferred package manager to install Blend:



Basic Setup

1. Start Using Components



2. Theme Configuration (Optional)

Configure your application theme:



Framework-Specific Setup

Next.js Configuration

For Next.js applications, add this to your next.config.js:



TypeScript Configuration

Ensure your tsconfig.json includes:



Development Environment Setup

For contributors or those wanting to run the project locally:

Prerequisites

- Node.js 18+ and pnpm
- Git for version control

Setup Steps



Best Practices

Component Usage

- Always refer to our component documentation for API reference
- Use TypeScript for better development experience and type safety
- Follow established patterns for consistent implementation

Design Tokens

- Use design tokens instead of hardcoded values
- Reference our design tokens guide for available tokens
- Maintain consistency with the design system guidelines

Next Steps

1. Explore Components: Browse our component library
2. Learn Design Tokens: Understand our foundation system
3. Contributing: Check our contribution guide to contribute to the project
4. Get Support: Join our community discussions for help and feedback

That's it! You're ready to start building with Blend Design System.
